body:
Currently and for the immediate future the answer is no. We have been
careful with internal API layering to allow for this possibility in the
future it's not work we anticipate doing ourselves right now. As has been
mentioned on some other recent threads there's a lot of performance fruit
that remains to be picked and we're going to focus on that.

Specifically for MQ and NATS what do you perceive as their advantages vs
using HTTP2. It's my working assumption that since HTTP2 will have standard
internet infrastructure support that messaging systems will move to using
HTTP2 over time since it gives them streaming & flow-control support at the
transport layer and that they would layer message reliability semantics
over that.

On Tue, Aug 30, 2016 at 11:38 AM, Arun Gopalpuri notifications@github.com
wrote:

> I see that gRPC uses http2 as transport protocol. Is there a way to change
> or override the default http2 protocol to MQ or NATS as the transport
> protocol?
> 
> —
> You are receiving this because you are subscribed to this thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/7931, or mute the thread
> https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AIoKPGjauO2hPQcxSBMTiouA56Gs14Owks5qlHidgaJpZM4Jw1vx
> .

Looking for pub/sub implementation and features like at-least-once-delivery, fanout, topic identification or ACLs that a pub/sub broker implementation would provide like e.g. NATS. 

Just want to use NATS only for inter service communication and http2 of external facing gRPC services.

These are apples and oranges.

NATS provides a brokered (i.e hub & spoke) pub-sub system, GRPC is
primarily designed for peer-to-peer communications between services and
generally sits at a lower level in the stack. We would not consider adding
messaging semantics like at-least-once-delivery to GRPC as it would be
layering violation.

These technologies can be complimentary as GRPC streaming support gives a
way for pubsub systems with proprietary wire formats like NATS to bridge to
the internet at large. Google's Cloud PubSub API does this for example. It
shouldn't be hard to write these bridges yourself

wrote:

> .

@derekcollison

FWIW I think NATS is pretty awesome. If I had time I'd be interested in
trying to hack GRPC+Proto as the transport mechanism into NATS to see if we
could get it close to the performance of it's native protocol.

Derek's talk on doing transport optimizations in Go is a great listen ...

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ylRKac5kSOk&feature=youtu.be

... and GRPC Go has not gotten that far yet in its optimization work.

> > .

@arun0009 

It might work using grpc-gateway..

SO instead of changing NATS, you can possibly layer GRPC.gateway on top
Because GRPC IS a DSL, its easy to code gen, so you could probably code gen a layer to put the GRPC data onto the NATS message bus.
You would get all the nice things about GRPC and NATS without forking or messing wth either.

Not saying this is the way, but just thinking out loud about it.

Thanks @joeblew99 We did end up doing the exact same thing you mentioned above - adding https://github.com/mwitkow/grpc-proxy and passing data over NATS and a hook on the server side to take data and call the server implementation. It might not be the best solution but it works without any framework changes like you mentioned.

More on allowing the option to swap out HTTP/2: Maybe you have clients like IoT devices with high packet loss and/or latency that HTTP/2 (or rather the TCP it runs on) won't handle well. There are protocols designed to handle this with preemptive retransmission, for one. Also, you need in-order messages for gRPC streaming methods but not for regular method calls, so using TCP for everything introduces unnecessary slowdowns when high packet loss is involved.
